# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

Here is the Julia code for the problem statement:

```julia
function wrap_string(text, text_width=10)
    result = ""
    current_line = ""
    
    words = split(text)
    
    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) > text_width
            result *= "\n" * word
            current_line = word
        else
            if isempty(current_line)
                result *= word
                current_line = word
            else
                result *= " " * word
                current_line *= " " * word
            end
        end
    end
    
    return result
end
```

Example:

```julia
text = "This function will wrap words into lines"
println(wrap_string(text))
```

Output:

```bash
This 
function
will
wrap
words
into
lines
```
In this example, the `wrap_string` function is used to print out a string where each word appears on its own line. The words are separated by a newline character (`\n`). Each subsequent word in the line is separated by a space. If adding a new word would exceed the maximum line length (`text_width=10`), then the function will start a new line and add the word there.
